title: Configuring Postman
content:
Introduction

Service Management allows users to access and modify data using a REST API. In order to use the REST API a REST tool needs to be configured. A commonly used tool available is Postman.

Normally, you can use Postman to do smoke testing and prototyping of APIs to figure out their connection settings and payload formats, as a preparation step for setting up integration solutions in your real production environment.

This topic will cover:

  • Installing Postman
  • Creating a Workspace and Collection
  • Sending and receiving back the login token
  • Sending a REST command to create an entity using the EMS API
  • Sending a REST command to get an entity using the EMS API

Installing Postman

Postman is a free application available on the Postman website. The instructions below are for the downloaded application and not the web version of the utility. To download access https://www.postman.com/downloads/ and select the Windows 64-bit download.

Double click on the Postman-win64-<version>.exe to launch the installation.

Creating a Workspace and Collection

On first launch, Postman will require a user to create a login and password. After logging in, add a new workspace that will contain all the REST collections.

After selecting the Workspace, add a new Collection so that the REST configurations can be saved and reused.

Once the collection has been created, the “add a request” option becomes available.

Sending and receiving the login token

To run a REST call on a Service Management tenant, an LWSSO_Cookie_Key must be provided.  To obtain this key requires users to first run a REST call that authorizes the session.

Select the POST option and then add the URL and the tenant ID. For example: “https://<HOSTNAME>/auth/authentication-endpoint/authenticate/token?TENANTID=484980393”

Set the Authorization to “No Auth”

In the Headers section, set the Content-Type to “application/json”.

Select raw for the Body type and then add the user that will be used to authenticate. The content must be in json format. For example: “{"Login":"A-login","Password":"ThePassword"}”

Click on the send button and a large string of characters will be returned from the authentication service.

Sending a REST command to create an entity using the EMS API

Click on the “+” to add a new REST configuration. Enter the URL for the EMS API. For example: https://smaxswinfra.net/rest/484980393/ems/bulk. Select the Post option, set the Authorization to “no auth”. In the Headers section add the Content-Type of application/json and set the User-Agent to Apache-HttpClient/4.1. Copy the string retrieved in the authentication step and then add a Cookie Key and set it to be SMAX_AUTH_TOKEN=<String from the authentication>

The Body will consist of the REST payload that needs to be sent to create something in Service Management. The body needs to be in json format and contain all the required fields that the workflow will need.

Assuming all the required fields are present, the EMS API will return the ID of the entity that was created.
